content: The "Federal Oil and Gas Reform Act of 1999" is cited as the short title. Section 109 of the Federal Oil and Gas Royalty Management Act of 1982 is amended to include civil penalties for violations related to federal oil and gas royalties. Section 109 of the Federal Oil and Gas Royalty Management Act of 1982 is amended to include civil penalties for violations related to federal oil and gas royalties, such as failure to comply with requirements, make royalty payments, or submit accurate information. The Federal Oil and Gas Royalty Management Act of 1982 is amended to include civil penalties for violations related to federal oil and gas royalties, such as failure to make royalty payments or submit accurate information. Violations may result in penalties equal to three times the unpaid royalty amount plus interest, as well as civil penalties. The Federal Oil and Gas Royalty Management Act of 1982 now includes civil penalties for violations related to federal oil and gas royalties. Violations may result in penalties equal to three times the unpaid royalty amount plus interest, as well as civil penalties of $25,000 per violation per day. There are provisions for reporting and correcting violations within 30 days to avoid penalties. Additionally, failure to notify the Secretary of designated information may result in lease administration violations. Any person who fails to report a violation to the Secretary or designated representative and corrects it, or fails to notify the Secretary of designations or assignments under a lease, permit entry, inspection, or audit, or comply with notification requirements regarding lease activities. Any person who fails to comply with inspection, audit, notification, or reporting requirements may be subject to a penalty of up to $10,000 per violation per day. Additionally, theft of oil or gas without legal authority is prohibited. Any person who fails to comply with management responsibilities may face penalties of up to $10,000 per violation per day. Theft of oil or gas without legal authority can result in penalties of up to $25,000 per violation per day. Repeated violations will lead to notification and demand for compliance by the Secretary or their designee. Repeated violations of subsections (a), (b), or (c) may result in a notification and demand for compliance by the Secretary or their designee. Failure to comply within 30 days can lead to a civil penalty equal to 3 times the original penalty amount. If a person repeatedly violates subsections (a), (b), or (c), the Secretary may impose penalties such as shutting down production, prohibiting lease acquisition, and canceling lease interests. The Secretary may impose penalties on a person for violating oil or gas lease regulations, including shutting down production, prohibiting lease acquisition, canceling lease interests, and collecting reimbursement for costs incurred. Any determination of royalties or penalties owed is final unless appealed within 15 days. The Secretary can impose penalties for violating oil or gas lease regulations, including production shutdowns and lease cancellations. Any royalty or penalty determinations are final unless appealed within 15 days. Appeals must be made in accordance with regulations issued by the Secretary, who can also compromise or reduce civil penalties on a case-by-case basis. Penalties may be deducted from sums owed by the United States to the charged person. The Secretary can impose penalties for violating oil or gas lease regulations, including production shutdowns and lease cancellations. Penalties may be deducted from sums owed by the United States to the charged person. The Secretary has the authority to compromise or reduce civil penalties on a case-by-case basis. Notice of penalties shall be served personally or by registered mail, and individuals can designate a representative to receive such notices. The Secretary must provide reasons for penalty determinations and any remittance or reduction decisions. Judicial review is available for individuals who request a hearing within the specified time frame. The Secretary can impose penalties for violating oil or gas lease regulations, with the option for remittance or reduction. Judicial review is available for aggrieved individuals within 90 days of the Secretary's final order. Failure to pay penalties may result in consequences. The district court review of violations is limited to the administrative record within 90 days of the Secretary's final order. Failure to pay penalties can lead to court-awarded amounts plus interest. No person can violate the Mineral Leasing Act. The court can award the assessed amount plus interest after a final judgment in favor of the Secretary. No civil penalty for failure to pay rent for a lease terminated under the Mineral Leasing Act. Violations toll statutes of limitations until corrected and certified. The Secretary or their designee can toll the statute of limitations for oil and gas leases if a violation is found, until the violation is corrected and certified, or a final order is issued. The person must also maintain all records until released from the obligation. A person found to have violated certain subsections must maintain all records related to their oil and gas leases until released from the obligation or until the records must be maintained under section 103(b). Amounts received by the United States in actions for underpayment of royalties will be treated as royalties paid under the lease for mineral leasing laws and the Land and Water Conservation Fund Act of 1965. Shared Civil Penalties: Section 206 of the Federal Oil and Gas Royalty Management Act of 1982 is amended to include trebled royalties or 50% of any civil penalty. The second sentence is removed.
